verb

abolish

to officially end a law, a system or an institution

noun

abortion

the deliberate ending of a pregnancy at an early stage

noun

absence

the fact of somebody being away from a place where they are usually expected to be; the occasion or period of time

when somebody is away fffff

adjective

absent

not in a place because of illness, etc.

verb

absorb

to take in a liquid, gas or other substance from the surface or space around

adjective

abstract

based on general ideas and not on any particular real person, thing or situation

adjective

absurd

extremely silly; not logical and sensible

noun

abundance

a large quantity that is more than enough

noun

abuse

the use of something in a way that is wrong or harmful

verb

abuse

to make bad use of something, or to use so much of something that it harms your health

noun

academy

a school or college for special training

verb

accelerate

to happen faster or earlier; to make something happen faster or earlier

noun

accent

a way of pronouncing the words of a language that shows which country, area or social class a person comes

from; how well somebody pronounces a particular language fffff

noun

acceptance

the act of accepting a gift, an invitation, an offer, etc.

adjective

accessible

that can be reached, entered, used, seen, etc.

adverb

accidentally

by chance; in a way that was not planned

verb

accommodate

to provide somebody with a room or place to sleep, live or sit

verb

accomplish

to succeed in doing or completing something

noun

accomplishment

an impressive thing that is done or achieved after a lot of work

noun

accordance

according to a rule or the way that somebody says that something should be done

to make something clearer or easier to understand

noun

clarity

the quality of being expressed clearly

noun

clash

a short fight between two groups of people

noun

classification

the act or process of putting people or things into a group or class (= of classifying them)

verb

classify

to arrange something in groups according to features that they have in common

noun

clerk

a person whose job is to serve customers in a shop

noun

cliff

a high area of rock with a very steep side, often at the edge of the sea or ocean

verb

cling

to hold on tightly to somebody/something

noun

clinic

a building or part of a hospital where people can go for special medical treatment or advice

adjective

clinical

relating to the examination and treatment of patients and their illnesses

noun

clip

a short part of a film that is shown separately

noun

closure

the situation when a factory, school, hospital, etc. shuts permanently

noun

cluster

a group of things of the same type that grow or appear close together

noun

coalition

a government formed by two or more political parties working together

adjective

coastal

of or near a coast

noun

cocktail

a drink usually made from a mixture of one or more spirits (= strong alcoholic drinks) and fruit juice. It can also be

made without alcohol. fffff

adjective

cognitive

connected with mental processes of understanding

verb

coincide

to take place at the same time

noun

coincidence

the fact of two things happening at the same time by chance, in a surprising way

the act of preventing somebody/something from entering a place or taking part in something

adjective

exclusive

only to be used by one particular person or group; only given to one particular person or group

adverb

exclusively

for only one particular person, group or use

verb

execute

to kill somebody, especially as a legal punishment

noun

execution

the act of killing somebody, especially as a legal punishment

verb

exert

to use power or influence to affect somebody/something

noun

exhibit

an object or a collection of objects put in a public place, for example a museum, so that people can see it

verb

exhibit

to show something in a public place for people to enjoy or to give them information

noun

exile

the state of being sent to live in another country that is not your own, especially for political reasons or as a punishment

noun

exit

a way out of a public building or vehicle

verb

exit

to go out; to leave a building, stage, vehicle, etc.

adjective

exotic

from or in another country, especially a tropical one; seeming exciting and unusual because it seems to be

connected with foreign countries fffff

noun

expansion

an act of increasing or making something increase in size, amount or importance

noun

expenditure

the act of spending or using money; an amount of money spent

adjective

experimental

based on new ideas, forms or methods that are used to find out what effect they have

noun

expertise

expert knowledge or skill in a particular subject, activity or job

verb

expire

to be no longer legally acceptable because the period of time for which it could be used has ended

adjective

explicit

clear and easy to understand, so that you have no doubt what is meant

adverb

explicitly

clearly or directly, so that the meaning is easy to understand

mean ‘supermarket’. fffff

usually to try to change the government fffff

something difficult fffff

trees that are grown to be used in building or for making things

adjective

cramped

a cramped room, etc. does not have enough space for the people in it

adjective

extremely modern and unusual in appearance, as if belonging to a future time

adjective

introducing or using new ideas, ways of doing something, etc.

a large building with several floors for parking cars in

adjective

prefabricated

made in sections that can be put together later

verb

to say very strongly that you think something is bad, usually for moral reasons

verb

to pull or knock down a building; to destroy something

verb

to be different from something; to do something in a different way from what is usual or expected

verb

reconstruct

to build or make something again that has been damaged or that no longer exists

verb

renovate

noun

noun

combining form

hindsight

the understanding that you have of a situation only after it has happened and that means you would have done things

in a different way fffff

example buildings, transport and water and power supplies fffff

/ˌɡləʊbələˈzeɪʃn/

noun

tolerance

the quality of being willing to accept or tolerate somebody/something, especially opinions or behaviour that

you may not agree with, or people who are not like you fffff

the production or sending out of light, heat, gas, etc.

too valuable or special to be replaced

a person who steals money, etc. from other people’s pockets, especially in crowded places

more shocking than they really are fffff

to continue doing something that has already been started; to continue being done

verb

prohibit

to stop something from being done or used especially by law

noun

prospect

the possibility that something will happen

noun

protocol

a system of fixed rules and formal behaviour used at official meetings, usually between governments

noun

psychology

the scientific study of the mind and how it influences behaviour

noun

publication

the act of printing a book, a magazine, etc. and making it available to the public; a book, a magazine, etc. that has

been published fffff

verb

purchase

to buy something

verb

pursue

to do something or try to achieve something over a period of time

adjective

qualitative

connected with what something is like or how good it is, rather than with how much of it there is

adjective

radical

relating to the most basic and important parts of something; complete and detailed

adjective

random

done, chosen, etc. without somebody deciding in advance what is going to happen, or without any regular pattern

noun

ratio

the relationship between two groups of people or things that is represented by two numbers showing how much larger

one group is than the other fffff

adjective

rational

based on reason rather than emotions

noun

verb

noun

the feeling of being unwilling to do something and hesitating before you do it, because you do not want to do it or

because you are not sure that it is the right thing to do fffff

verb

to live in a particular place

verb

verb

verb

to stop somebody/something from doing something, especially by using physical force

verb

to limit the size, amount or range of something

verb

to keep something; to continue to have something

verb

to make something known to somebody

noun

the money that a government receives from taxes or that an organization, etc. receives from its business

verb

reverse

to change something completely so that it is the opposite of what it was before

noun

revolution

an attempt, by a large number of people, to change the government of a country, especially by violent action

adjective

rigid

very strict and difficult to change

noun

scenario

a description of how things might happen in the future

their prices can be kept low fffff
